awd_titl_txt: RIDIR: Developing and Deploying the Criminal Justice Administrative Records System
awd_abstract_narration:
The Criminal Justice Administrative Records System (CJARS) is a project created to address gaps in the existing data infrastructure of the U.S. criminal justice system.  The U.S. criminal justice system has six million individuals under correctional supervision and requires hundreds of billions of dollars in public expenditures. Scholars and policymakers have consistently called for robust, scientific analysis quantifying the benefits and costs of justice practices, yet this goal has been fundamentally constrained by limitations including a lack of data integration across agencies and jurisdictions as well as an inability to measure outcomes in social and economic domains.  CJARS addresses these gaps by collecting administrative data from criminal justice agencies across the U.S., harmonizing event data into a common national format, and linking person-level records to form longitudinal histories of life course interactions with the justice system.  In partnership with the U.S. Census Bureau, CJARS data will be made available in Federal Statistical Research Data Centers, where criminal justice data can be integrated with a wide range of socioeconomic survey and administrative data, and thus support a new generation of innovative research on the U.S. criminal justice system.

This project involves three areas of activity: (1) preparation of CJARS for external research access by benchmarking it to existing statistical series and performing advanced validation checks based on integrated criminal and non-criminal microdata; (2) production of novel research on the U.S. justice system that illustrates the breadth of possibilities enabled by the CJARS platform; and (3) development of access infrastructure and launching of outreach activities to engage a large and diverse user base. The research includes studies of the prevalence of criminal justice interactions across the U.S. and the methodology of harmonizing administrative records. Outreach activities will raise awareness of data and research opportunities, facilitate new research proposals, and maximize the scientific value of the infrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the grant titled "Developing and Deploying the Criminal Justice Administrative Records System (CJARS)" was to create a new state-of-the-art criminal justice data platform and to conduct outreach to develop a user-base for the data resource. CJARS is an integrated micro-level data resource that incorporates data from law enforcement agencies, criminal courts, and corrections agencies into one harmonized database. This provides significant value to researchers, policy-makers, and the general public because the decentralized nature of criminal justice data in the United States has historically inhibited the creation of knowledge about the system and its impact on people's lives.

The NSF grant (1925563) was awarded to the University of Michigan where a team of researchers and data scientists led the initial development of the CJARS data platform. The project team collaborated with researchers at the U.S. Census Bureau to incorporate CJARS into the Federal Statistical Research Data Center (FSRDC) network to make it accessible for research and statistical purposes. The FSRDC network is a data ecosystem managed by the U.S. Census Bureau that serves as a central repository for a rich set of linkable administrative and survey data resources that have been integrated into the system (e.g., CJARS, Decennial Censuses, American Community Survey). The major advantage of the FSRDC network is that it facilitates secure linkage of data resources at the individual-level which creates new opportunities to conduct research on the criminal justice system that was previously impossible.

This funding provided the resources necessary to achieve a number of outcomes that supported the primary goals of the project, which are described in more detail below.

The CJARS data platform was launched in March 2021 and involved its integration into the U.S. Census Bureau's FSRDC network which made the data resources available to qualified researchers that apply for access. Several vintages of the CJARS database have been released since initial launch with the most recent vintage covering data from 34 states and includes data on 233 million criminal justice events and 48 million people. The user base of CJARS in the FSRDC network has grown steadily and currently has been requested in 41 projects. These projects include 124 researchers hailing from 36 unique institutions.  

The CJARS team conducted user outreach and developed additional data products and tools to expand its user base. One way this was accomplished was by holding a fellowship program that provided funding for early career-stage researchers that proposed projects using the CJARS database. We also disseminated a data tool that we developed to process data incorporated into CJARS because it provides value to the broader researcher community. Specifically, we publicly released the Text-based Offense Classification (TOC) tool in July 2022 which is a machine learning algorithm that classifies descriptions of criminal offenses into a pre-defined data schematic. A total of 212 people have registered to use TOC and they have used to tool to process over 1,300 data files. Finally, we developed the Justice Outcomes Explorer (JOE) to create an easier way to access CJARS-produced statistics. JOE is a publicly available web-based data dashboard that hosts millions of aggregate statistics that we produced using the CJARS database that were linked to other administrative and survey data available within the FSRDC network. The statistics available through JOE cover the size of criminal justice agency caseloads and outcomes of justice-involved individuals related to their recidivism, employment, earnings, health, and enrollment in social benefit programs. The goal of creating JOE was to provide a low-barrier access mechanism so that a wider user-base could benefit from CJARS-produced statistics. Since its launch in May 2024, JOE has seen about 6,500 users visit the site and data from the site has been downloaded 280 times.

Finally, the project team carried out new research using the CJARS database that was previously impossible because of a lack of available data. The research that has been conducted has stretched across various disciplines and has answered some basic questions that we previously did not have answers to. The project team carried out research on the impact of changes to social benefits policies and subsequent criminal justice involvement, exposure of children to the criminal justice system through their parents, and the impact of changes to the age of criminal majority on subsequent outcomes. These research projects provided career advancement opportunities for project team members at various career stages, including undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral research fellow, and early-stage faculty. The methods developed to link and analyze data in these projects have seeded follow-on studies which have continued to support the research agendas of those involved.


Last Modified: 11/23/2024
Modified by: Michael Mueller-Smith
